Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 04:42AM ohio4me wrote: Susan - that's a lot to handle in such a short time. I am in the medical field (radiology) so all the testing, etc. was familiar territory. I saw my mammo images, knew it wasn't good, knew what was coming, so nothing was really a surprise as it unfolded. The biggest challenge was being the patient on the table instead of behind the control panel. I managed a breast center and knew what to expect every step of the way - - but it was so difficult to apply all the knowledge to me personally. I was used to giving the information to someone else and had no experince in how to receive the info for me. This wasn't professional, it was personal - my two worlds collided. Both my sisters are nurses, one an oncology nurse. They were both wonderful but they struggled applying their skill to me - their sister. It was just an entirely different set of circumstances. We were all much more familiar being on the giving side of healthcare than the receiving end. And, yes, I was terrified (still am on occasion). I did well until chemo started and then took Ativan as needed. What worked for me - I lived in the present. I can't change the past, can't control the future but I could decide for today. It's just one day at a time. One day. You only need to deal with today. And don't bottle up the emotions. Tears are good - just let them flow when needed. I sent email updates to a large group of family and friends and that was my therapy. I found writing down my emotions and documenting my day/week made me put things in perspective in order to make sense in the email. I told them when I had a meltdown and when I had good days. I found humor in lots of things (like the nasal hairs). Our family has always found humor easily and that served me well. I didn't know about these discussion groups at the time but I had several friends with BC and they were very helpful in sharing stories and support. There is a good website, chemocare.org, sponsored by Cleveland Clinic that helps understand chemo side effects. There was another book, Breast Cancer Treatment Handbook by Kneece, that was a huge resource. It was my guide through the process. Even though I knew the process, I needed guidance and that book was my 'what's next' guide. I only read the chapters I needed as the events occurred. Best wishes to you.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 04:01PM ohio4me wrote: Like most things in life, mammography is not 100% but it is still the best breast screening tool. Some cancer, like lobular, does not appear easily in the early stages. The best defense is mammography plus self breast exam plus clinical breast exam. Additional imaging is available as needed. Mammos aren't that fun but the squish is for seconds. I always recommend mammography. Mine cancer didn't show early but that isn't true for all.
Posts.Title: Mammogram/Radiologist did not see cancer - anyone else? Del5 Calameda

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 04:20PM ohio4me wrote: Things to look for at a mammo facility. In the US, mammography centers (every site doing mammography) is required to meet regulations set forth by the federal government. Wherever you go for a mammogram, you should see a certificate posted that says the facility is 'FDA Accreditated'. If you don't see the sign, ask if they are accredited. Technologists and radiologists are required to perform an minimum number of mammos annually and continuing education to remain proficient. Ask your tech if he/she is certified and has experience. Once you know your facility has meet all the regulations, you need to realize there are some diagnosis that do not visualize well on mammograms. If you have dense breasts, ask for further testing. Six states have already passed legislation that requires you, the patient, to be notified in your 'lay letter' if you have dense breasts. Those states are: Virginia, Texas, New York, Hawaii, Connecticut, and California. Other states and federal legislation are pending. If you are not in one of those states, you need to call your provided and ask if you have dense breasts. There is a good website dedicated to dense breasts:http://www.areyoudense.org/ Dense breasts increase risk of failing to detect cancer on a mammogram. Be aggressive in pursuing additional testing if you fall into that category.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 12:49PM ohio4me wrote: Wow - you have a lot of information there. My suggestion is to get notebook, right down all your questions and go with your mom to her next appt. Just list all the things you identified above and that will give you a really good start. You can search the articles here on breastcancer.org to get good resource information. I'll try to give some input be you need to realize everyone is unique so you do need to lean on your medical staff for the correct path for your mom. No mammo and how far has it spread - based on the pathology, physical exam and doctor recommendations, there are some tests to help determine if the cancer is spread further. That could be a PET scan or a CT Scan or an MR - you need to trust your docs to recommend what is right for her. Pathology results - you can ask for a copy of the pathology results. It should have ER+, etc. and grade. Staging will most likely be determined by the oncologist when all the tests are in. It's a bit nerve racking but it just takes some time. Most important is to get the process started. Mastectomy or not - the surgeon may have recommendations but you can ask all those questions. My surgeon gave me a book 'Breast Cancer Treatment Handbook: Understanding the Disease, Treatments, emotions, and Recovery from Breast Cancer' by Judy Kneece. You can get it on Amazon. I found this book to be a very good resource. The internet can get overwhelming, this book was great and even lists reputable websites for quality information. It even gives you questions to ask. Your mom is lucky to have you help sort through these details.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2012 10:07AM ohio4me wrote: I had a PET/CT after surgery and before chemo. I had ILC, MX and positive nodes so a PET/CT was a good option. While everyone is different, if you have surgery with clear margins and negative nodes you may not be a candidate for a PET/CT. Depends on how closely your doc, facility, and insurance follow appropriateness guidelines. My thot at the time was to get all the pre-testing possible. I made me feel better just knowing we wer covering all the basis.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 08:27AM ohio4me wrote: There is a Lebed DVD that has good stretching exercises for the lymphatic system. It helps keep the fluid moving, etc. It's called The Lebed Methed Focus on Healing - you can even get it on Amazon. There is a whole series of exercises but I usually do the 15 minute opening session. Feels good and the lymph system likes it. Flexi-Touch is a pneumatic system that massages the chest and arm. My insurance covered this equipment and I used it quite a bit this summer when my arm just wasn't happy in the heat. Here is the website: http://www.tactilesystems.com/flexitouch/index.html A bonus of the Lebed exercises - I had lymph node dissection plus radiation to the axilla and those muscles get tight quickly. Stretching exercises have helped the whole radiated area to stay 'healthy' - even my RO is pleased. So much to learn...

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2012 10:47AM ohio4me wrote: Purple - I was told to wear my sleeve during the day and not at night. I found that bothersome. Through trial and error (and only during cooler weather) I find I can go without my sleeve during the day if I pace myself when doing repetitive tasks like laundry, etc. Sometimes it takes all day to fold clothes but I chose that over the sleeve. I always wear my sleeve when exercising, doing repetitive work that I want to get done (cleaning garage) or during the heat of summer, oh, and I always wear to doctor appts so they think I am compliant.  I do a lot of Lebed type stretches during the day while sitting at my desk and I drink a lot of water, usually 16 oz. daily. Water is my favorite beverage so that is easy, stretching feels good so I do it often. I do need to get better at deep breathing throughout the day. Initally, I was Stage II LE (by my MO) with my forearm and hand showing the most swelling. It took a much time to get my hand to normal but I am fortunate I have not any severe flare ups. I see an LE trained massage therapist as needed and haven't been to PT in over a year. My sister helps measure my arm regularly to confirm everything is as good as I think.   I spend about 20-30 minutes on MLD each night and sometimes longer - depends on the TV show I'm watching :) It took me a year to feel confident I was doing MLD correctly, to know I had the tools/knowledge to manage my LE, and feel a sense of 'freedom' to live my life without fear of an LE flare-up. Coming from a medical background, I had to do a lot of reading to understand the physiology behind LE. Once I had a better understanding of LE I felt empowered to manage it. Just keep asking, keep trying, and you will get there.

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 05:11AM ohio4me wrote: Shary - you need protein and lots of water to get you through chemo. Your healthy cells need that protein to keep your blood levels in good order to continue on your chemo schedule. Eat protein and drink water whether they taste good or not. In the long run - you would rather force feed yourself then delay a chemo treatment because blood levels aren't good. If you have access to a nutritionist, make an appointment and find out how much protein you need daily - don't go less than what is recommended for your weight - you probably need more during chemo. Fruit is good - but you need a better diet to help your healthy cells get through chemo. I was on ACT also and got really bad metal mouth and bread tasted like cardboard but be creative and get the protein and drink lots of water daily.

I would suggest getting one if you can. Gives me confidence I have all the tools I need for home care.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2012 09:17PM - edited Aug 19, 2012 09:30PM by ohio4me Kidsandlabs - good luck on both. I had my port and first chemo the day so my first chemo is a fog - not a bad thing. The port never bothered me at all, hopefully that will be your experience also. As for chemo, drink lots of water and eat a lot of protein. Your cells are gonna need both. My goal was 80-90 grams of protein daily and 8-10 glasses of water. My labs were always good so was able to stay on my chemo schedule, no delayed treatments , no transfusions. Medical staff thinks the diet was key - at least for me. I admit I was force feeding protein some days and only made 60 grams days - but that is still good. Don't know if this will help for you. I actually met with a nutritionist before chemo who gave me the protein and water goals. If you are anywhere near Akron, there is place called Stewart's Caring Place that offers free nutrition counseling. My first chemo was Aug 27, 2011 and here I am with curly hair and feeling good. Hope all goes well for you. If you are near Akron-Canton and want to meet for coffee just send a private message. All the best. Diane

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 06:26AM ohio4me wrote: Dana, welcome. You have come to right place to find information and support through these times. You must be overwhelmed. My surgeon gave me a book that was a great resource for me. It is Breast Cancer Treatment Handbook by Judy Kneece, RN, OCN. You can find it on Amazon for about $25.00. I sat and read the book through (which was overwhelming) and then used it chapter by chapter as my treatment progressed. You will gain much good info on these boards but I found the book a great resource. There is also a list of reputable websites to access for information. With surgery coming soon, you need to know how to care for yourself afterwards. My recommendation is to be cautious with exercise and range of motion exercises the first two weeks after surgery. I started range of motion exercises a bit soon and probably promoted my possibility of lymphedema. You may want to surf through this website for some pre-reading http://stepup-speakout.org/. No one wants lymphedema but if they do a sentinel node biopsy you will be at risk.  You may want to Private Message Carol57 or Binney and ask for their post surgery recommendations. Not everyone gets lymphedema but the risk exists. Best wishes. Keep us posted and always feel free to ask questions.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 03:46AM ohio4me wrote: Didn't have a red face. Not sure what that might be. I had two of same chemos + Taxotere. Never had a red face. Did they tell you about mouth wash? I used an non-alchol mouthwash a lot - mininal 4-5 times daily to 'prevent' mouth sores. Never got sores. Either the mouthwash worked or that SE wasn't intended for me. Also lots of water - no less than 8 but usually 12 glasses daily. And lots of protein. I ate 90 grams of protein daily, sometimes I had to force feed but I got my water and protein in above all else. Never had issues with bloodwork dropping too low. MO and nurses were always pleased with my labs (me too!). Did you get a prescription for the nausea? I took Compazine chemo day and every 8 hours thereafter for 4-5 days - never got sick. Also took Ativan since the anticipation of SE's made me crazy. Those two pills sure helped chemo week go more smoothly. My sisters (both nurses) also had me taking stool softeners daily during chemo week. I learned that lesson after first treatment. I added Benefiber to my morning Malt-O-Meal every day., also. I knew SE's were coming, I was just determined to control the ones I could.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2012 10:00PM ohio4me wrote: My keys to successful air travel are: I do the Lebed opening and thorough MLD before the flight. I wear my sleeve and gauntlet in flight and for at least post flight. I 'exercise' during flight: deep breathing, arm stretches while making fists, at least one glass of water and modified MLD in flight. Modified meaning I clear my neck and do MLD through my sleeve. There is no proof that MLD through the sleeve is effective but I have been on many flights in the past year and this routine has worked for me. Once at my destination - lots of water and MLD an hour after flight or when settling into hotel. Repeat on return. Have lots of fun. I love the lights.

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 09:51PM ohio4me wrote: Truffles - I had the opportunity for six months paid leave (full pay) and did not take it (not that straightforward). Retrospectively, I could have taken more time. I work from home and had flexibility in my schedule but found some days where I just needed a nap. I had chemo every third Monday for six treatments and took off work Mon-Tues-Weds. I had TAC (Taxotere-Adriamycin-Cytoxan). I am a workaholic - and I did work as much as possible but I could not work my 8 hours/day for five days. Some days I struggled to get my hours in but would make up time on the weekend, some days I was conference calls while laying in bed. Radiation - I worked every day and made up hours on the weekend. About 3 weeks into radiation fatigue hit but usually in the early evening (about 5 PM). I had my radiation at 2:30 PM. I had good energy all day - just those evenings that hit hard at times. Radiation is daily - so if you can't get daily time off that could be an issue. If I could have kept my insurance and made if financially, I think I would have taken the time off - just wasn't a decision I had to make.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 04:59PM ohio4me wrote: cookiegal - I know how you feel. I was supposed to take a work trip to Italy this month and freaked out so the gal from Italy came to me. I have taken a few trips recently and they went well. As we all now, everybody has a different LE experience but here is what worked for me. I did the Lebed stretching exercises and full MLD before leaving for the airport and wore the compression sleeve and glove.  On the flight I drank a bottle of water (took it on the flight so I could start early). I also did some 'modified' MLD on the flight (as much MLD I as could) and modified Lebed. Both trips had layovers and all went well. I guess it's not the length of the flight but the altitude that makes the difference. I don't like the long flights and don't get many non-stops flights from my local airport. I just use all the tools I have have available and get on with my life. I'm bummed I let the Italy trip throw me into a tailspin. I didn't want to go (been there already) but I'm bummed I let LE make decisions for me. I will use all the tools I have and live my life. Yes, I will take every precautions but I don't intend to sit in my house forever. Don't know if that helps any - just make the decision you will not regret.

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2012 06:09AM ohio4me wrote: Kayleen - I agree with camillegal. If you are in any way uncomfortable with the results you can get copies of all tests and see another doctor. Sorry you had a unpleasant experience during testing. Back in the old days of healthcare (my field) we were given more time to talk with patients and address fears. It is unfortunate those days are gone and there is so much focus on volume - the patient gets lost in the shuffle to stay afloat. Not a good thing but prevalent in heathcare these days. When I go to the doctor I have my list of questions and I don't leave until I get my answers. You need to be an advocate for your own healthcare. Get your films - get a second opinion. Put your mind at rest. When/if you feel another lump get it checked out - never assume the next time it will be nothing. Here's hoping everything really is negative and just normal breast changes. During menopause breast tissue does change but it's always good to follow-up with concerns.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 07:32AM ohio4me wrote: Victoria - I think I'm doing a pretty good job managing my LE but, at the beginning, I had reservations about whether I was doing MLD correctly. Yes, I had a good LE-T that showed me MLD and gave me a chart, etc. But as the days passed I just wasn't sure I remembered everything correctly. I went to this website (Rovig) and watched every online video about CDT and MLD, etc. It was very educational and gave me the confidence I needed to know I was doing MLD correctly and why I was doing it in the order the LE-T prescribed. Don't know if these videos will help you but it was my confirmation that I was on the right track. http://www.nwlymphedemacenter.org/index.html I do MLD nightly, not wearing my sleeve during the cooler weather (always have it with me if needed), don't wear night garments, don't wear my sleeve/glove when working in the kitchen - I just pace myself with what I do. I may be taking some risk not protecting my hand in the kitchen but it's working for me. I am doing more things left-handed (I'm a righty) which causes more mess and spillage at times but it is what it is. I wear OTC Juzo sleeves/gloves and they go in the washer and dryer.  It's the summer heat/humidity that makes my LE unhappy but Little Martha (LE arm) sure is liking winter.
